args: Oof. I almost fumbled big-time.\nAppreciate the save, Isaac!
Oh, I'm bringing a bunch of supplies to\nhelp with village reconstruction work.
Allow me to carry some. I'd be happy to\nhelp with the restoration effort as well.
Do you object to me coming along?
It's not that, it's just... Ah, forget it.\nYou sure you don't mind helping?
We've been awaiting your arrival, Sarisse.\nAh, and thank you for your assistance,\nIsaac.
Heya, Cleo! Your carpentry tools,\nas requested! Where's my bro?
He's off to help cut trees down with the\nothers to supplement the lumber supply.
Cleo! Got a moment?\nSomeone's been hurt.
Certainly. My apologies to you both, but\nI'll need to step away for a little while.
Tell me something, Sarisse...\nWas this village formed by clearing forest?
Yes. Luca started it—to create a place\nwhere different races could live as one.
You mean to say that LUCA did this?!\nAll these trees fell at his hand?
There were other possible locations, but\nwe agreed that this was the ideal spot for\nwhat he wanted to accomplish.
Even so, to us, the forest is\nthe great mother—! But...wait.
Is that why you hesitated to bring me\nhere?
Yeah. But honestly? I wanted you to see\nit too, Isaac.
This village is a place that accepts\neveryone, regardless of their race\nor way of thinking.
I'm afraid I still don't fully understand.
See, we didn't have enough settlements\nfor the people of New Alberia to live in.

But this village is far more than that. More
than anything, it's the realization of Luca's
dream to create a home where humans,
rokkans, and sylvans can all live together.
It was attacked, though, and so now we're\ndoing reconstruction.
Hm. It would seem my offer to assist\ncomes at a critical juncture, then.
Would you, though? Even if we have\nto ask you to cut trees down to do it?
If this town was not destroyed by natural\ndisaster, then these woods have accepted\nit as well.
Further, I understand well the despair of\ndreams falling apart. I have no reason NOT\nto help.
(What am I hesitating about?\nI can't turn back now...)
Out on an evening walk, are you?
The very same. May I join you?
Your company would be most welcome...
Is there something on your mind?
It's written all over your face, and has been\nsince you were helping out with the village\nrestoration. I'm here to listen, if you wish.
You are a keen observer of people.\nYes... You have me sussed.

I came here to learn how I might change
my holy land for the better. And yet I am
so frightened of that change that I cannot
stand it.
To preserve the traditions and culture of\nthe sylvans, we must reform our laws\nregarding the holy land.
Initio has never allowed change, and\nunwittingly, this created friction with the\nworld beyond the forest.
That friction will only breed conflict and\ndestroy everything we've worked to protect.
Even so, I... I am afraid.\nMy knees tremble, betraying my resolve.
Fearing change is natural.\nI was the same way.
Yes. In the same way you revere the\nholy land, I have protected the Mistholt\nsince the era of the previous king's reign.
Yes. Of an age three centuries past.
Three hundred years?! How wrong I was\nto assume you among my generation...
Hee hee. Looks can be deceiving.
And a lot can change in three centuries.\nA different king. A different populace.
The interior of the castle—its very\natmosphere. I've felt lonely and afraid\nfacing all of these things and more.
It's like my memories of the past are\nbeing painted over...
How did you come to accept change,\nCleo?
I realized that even if their form changes,\nthe feelings remain the same.
{player_name} wishes for peace\nmore than anyone else, and he fights for\nit. His Majesty's feelings live on in him.
In that way, my old feelings continue on,\nunchanged. Realizing that helped me\nunderstand that change needn't be feared.
I suppose you might say...that it is a\nHalidom tradition to grow around a\nheart that yearns for peace.
A tradition, you say... And one you've\npreserved dutifully all these years.\nYou truly impress, Cleo.
You flatter me overmuch.\nLook, Isaac. This is what I think.
Tradition and culture exist as a way for\npeople to inherit the feelings of their\nancestors.
Yes... That is indeed the essence\nof tradition and culture.
Thus, my duty is to see those feelings\npassed on to the next generation, even\nif the form they take changes.
Thank you, Cleo. Now I can face\nchange with my head held high.

I hardly deserve thanks—you yourself
found that strength within. Now, shall we
head back? I'd be happy to brew us some
herbal tea if you need help winding down.
That would be lovely. Please do.\nI suspect I will dream well tonight.
